statement.text: The small saphenous vein (SSV) originates from the lateral marginal vein of the foot, ascends the posterior calf in the saphenous compartment, and terminates at the highly variable saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ), with critical proximity to the sural nerve requiring careful preoperative mapping for all SSV interventions.
statement.formal: SSV: Lateral_Malleolus → Posterior_Calf → SPJ (variable: popliteal fossa to mid-thigh) OR Giacomini_Vein → GSV

explanation.intuition: While the GSV is the main highway on the inside of the leg, the SSV is a smaller highway on the back of the calf. Unlike the predictable GSV, the SSV's endpoint (SPJ) is highly variable - it can join the deep system anywhere from behind the knee to the thigh, or connect to the GSV instead.
explanation.key_insight: The SPJ location varies so much that 'standard' surgical landmarks are unreliable. Ultrasound mapping is mandatory before any SSV intervention. Additionally, the sural nerve runs with the SSV below mid-calf, making thermal injury a significant risk - always use tumescent anesthesia for thermal ablation.
explanation.technical_details: The SSV originates posterior to the lateral malleolus from the lateral marginal vein. It ascends superficially in the lower calf, entering the saphenous compartment between the two heads of the gastrocnemius at mid-calf. The SSV lies in the posterior compartment bounded by the crural fascia superficially and deep fascia posteriorly. The SPJ location varies widely: it may enter the popliteal vein (classic), extend cranially as the Giacomini vein to join the GSV in the thigh, or drain into gastrocnemius veins. The sural nerve (medial and lateral components) runs closely with the SSV, converging below mid-calf.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: The SPJ is always at the popliteal crease. Reality: SPJ height is highly variable; it may be absent in 10-20% of patients.
Misconception: SSV treatment is similar to GSV. Reality: Prone positioning, variable SPJ, and sural nerve risk make SSV treatment distinct.
Misconception: Thermal injury to the sural nerve is rare. Reality: Without tumescent anesthesia, thermal nerve injury occurs in up to 10% of cases.

anatomic_course.origin: Lateral marginal vein of foot, posterior to lateral malleolus
anatomic_course.mid_calf: Enters saphenous compartment between gastrocnemius heads
anatomic_course.upper_calf: Within saphenous compartment, posterior to gastrocnemius

location_variability.high: May extend to mid-thigh before joining deep system
location_variability.absent: 10-20% have no true SPJ, drain via Giacomini vein

saphenopopliteal_junction.giacomini_vein: Cranial extension connecting SSV to GSV in posterior thigh

sural_nerve.course: Medial and lateral sural cutaneous nerves converge mid-calf to form sural nerve
sural_nerve.proximity: Runs closely with SSV in lower calf
sural_nerve.injury_risk: Thermal ablation without tumescent anesthesia risks injury

anatomic_relationships.popliteal_vessels: SSV crosses superficial to popliteal vessels at SPJ
anatomic_relationships.gastrocnemius: SSV lies between the two heads

anatomic_variants: True SPJ absent (drains via Giacomini vein) - 10-20%
presentation: Symptoms with standing, relief with elevation
Ankle flare (corona phlebectatica) on lateral ankle
Posterior calf skin changes (less common than GSV)
diagnosis: Map SPJ location (measure from popliteal crease)
Document sural nerve location if visible
treatment: Tumescent anesthesia mandatory for thermal ablation (nerve protection)
Foam sclerotherapy alternative for smaller SSV
Consider non-thermal ablation to reduce nerve injury risk

definition.@value: The superficial vein of the posterior calf originating from the lateral marginal vein, ascending in the saphenous compartment, and terminating at the highly variable saphenopopliteal junction, with critical proximity to the sural nerve.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
Journal of Vascular Surgery: Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

learning_objectives: Trace SSV course from foot to SPJ
Describe the relationship of SSV to sural nerve
Apply preoperative mapping for SSV procedures
clinical_pearls: SPJ location is HIGHLY variable - ALWAYS map with ultrasound before intervention
Sural nerve injury causes numbness on lateral foot and heel
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV - present in up to 20% as primary drainage
Use tumescent anesthesia for thermal SSV ablation to protect sural nerve
Position catheter 2-3cm from SPJ to protect popliteal vein

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
